Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Open XD Metrics on Demand Value Analytics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the value of campus-based cyberinfrastructure (CI) to the institutions that invest in such CI is intrinsically difficult. Given today's financial pressure, administrative support for campus-based CI centers offering resources to local campus users is under constant budgetary pressure. This is partly due to the difficulty in obtaining quantitative metrics that clearly demonstrate the utility of investment in campus CI centers in enhancing scientific research and the financial aspects of enhanced competitive ability in seeking funding for research.

This proposal seeks to implement a set of highly experimental modules to be added to the existing CI metrics tool eXtreme Data Metrics on Demand (XDMoD). These modules are intended to provide a means for assessing campus-based CI investment in scientific terms, as measured in publications, and in financial terms, as measured in grant income from researchers who use CI as compared to those who do not. The modules, tentatively called Open XDMoD Value Analytics, will present a view of financial, collaboration, and publication data, showing "return-on-investment" metrics in relation to CI usage. The goal of the work is to generalize these modules to work with a variety of funding and publication information sources, and incorporate them into the open source distribution of Open XDMoD.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the project was to provide campus administrators with tools allowing them to quantify and visualize their investment in advanced cyberinfrastructure (CI) resources. These tools do two things: 1) relate grant data (funding associated with a PI or Co-PI) to CI usage, and 2) relate scholarly publication data (journal publications associated with a PI or Co-PI) to CI usage. Previously, there was a lack of such metrics that clearly demonstrated the utility of investments in campus advanced CI centers in enhancing scientific research, and the financial aspects of enhanced competitive ability in seeking funding for research. Thus, it was difficult to demonstrate the relative contribution of CI to any new discovery, and there was little indication of how important campus-based CI was in reviews of grant proposals that were funded. Thus, we created a module (called Value Analytics) which is an extension to the Open XDMoD project. Open XDMoD is an open source tool to facilitate the management of high performance computing resources. It is widely deployed at academic, industrial and governmental high performance computing (HPC) centers. Open XDMoD’s management capabilities include monitoring standard metrics such as utilization, providing quality of service metrics designed to proactively identify underperforming system hardware and software, and reporting job level performance data for every job running on the HPC system without the need to recompile applications. The Value Analytics (VA) module adds capabilities which enable individuals to view the scholarly impact of investments in advanced CI. Moving forward, campuses and centers that utilize this module will be able to demonstrate relationships between grant awards, advanced CI usage, and scholarly publications.

 

 The Value Analytics module was released to the public on May 21st, 2018. It expanded the metrics available in the Open XDMoD application to include financial statistics, and provided visualizations to demonstrate relationships between grants, advanced CI usage, and publications. The Value Analytics module includes two visualizations: a co-pi collaboration network visualization and a funding and publication impact visualization. The visualization code is open source software hosted at https://github.com/cns-iu/XDMoD-Client. The XDMoD VA module has been installed at IU and Buffalo at http://rtstats-xdmod.uits.indiana.edu/ and https://va-demo.ccr.xdmod.org/ respectively.
